subject: My Position On the Syrian Refugees
event: Not like the brazen giant of Greek fame, With conquering limbs astride from land to land; Here at our sea-washed, sunset gates shall stand A mighty woman with a torch, whose flame Is the imprisoned lightning, and her name Mother of Exiles. From her beacon-hand Glows world-wide welcome; her mild eyes command The air-bridged harbor that twin cities frame. "Keep, ancient lands, your storied pomp!" cries she With silent lips. "Give me your tired, your poor, Your huddled masses yearning to breathe free, The wretched refuse of your teeming shore. Send these, the homeless, tempest-tost to me, I lift my lamp beside the golden door." Those words, of course, are by Emma Lazarus. Her poem, "The New Colossus," appears in bronze on the base of the Statue of Liberty. A statue given to the United States by France, our nation's oldest friend and ally... a bit of history that seems especially important just now, in light of the recent horrors in Paris. For me, Lady Liberty and the words on her base represent the best of what this nation of immigrants is all about. One has to wonder if all the governors (including our own governor here in New Mexico, I am ashamed to say) and congressmen voting to keep out the Syrian refugees have ever visited the Statue, or read the words on her base. If so, they surely failed to understand them. Of course, most everyone knows the part about 'your tired, your poor, your huddled masses,' but let me draw your attention to some other lines of the poem: -- a mighty woman with a torch... her name Mother of Exiles, -- from her beacon hand, Glows world-wide welcome, -- send these, the homeless, tempest-tost, to me. Emma Lazarus had it right. Donald Trump and thirty-one governors have it wrong, wrong, wrong. The Syrian refugees are as much victims of ISIS as the dead in France. Let them in. Santa Fe, at least, will welcome them.

comments.article: ... that a writer so good at teasing out the moral complexity of complicated situations in his books has such a simplistic view of a real world issue, where real lives are at steak. Surprised and disappointed.
comments.subject: Surprised...

comments.article: Real lives are at stake.  The lives of hundreds of thousands of Syrian refugees driven from their homes by war.  Many of them women and children.  That's the whole point.  There's a moral imperative here.

comments.article: ...aren't they simply following the example set by the greatest Democrat of all time, one Franklin Delano Roosevelt?
comments.subject: At the risk of sounding inflammatory...

comments.article:
FDR did many great things... but the Japanese internments and the refusal to allow more Jewish refugees to enter the US were his greatest sins, black marks on his legacy.

Do we really want to repeat those mistakes?

comments.article: The words on the Statue of Liberty were written before we had a welfare state. If you want them so much, why don't you let them stay at your house and you can pay for their medical bills. I'm sure you can afford it.
comments.subject: Let them stay at your house, George

comments.article: History has demonstrated many times that immigrants revitalize a society, and create much more than they take.  The sort of "they are just a bunch of lazy leeches" sentiment you are expressing here was also directed at the Irish, the Italians, the Germans, the Polish, the Chinese, and many other immigrant groups in the past, all of whom over time have vastly enriched the culture of America.  I have no doubt that the same will prove true of the Syrians.

comments.article: Finally a well reasoned and compassionate argument for taking refugees, where ever they may come.  Shameful to use recent events to deny sanctuary to those who need it most.
comments.subject: Thank you!

comments.article: I agree with this as much as anything you've ever written...which is high praise indeed for the guy who wrote the death of King Joffrey.
comments.subject: Agreed

comments.upictitle: a sudden absence of bees: books!
comments.article: Thank you for once again standing up for what's right. I'm a huge admirer of your writing, of course, but even more so, I admire that you lend your voice to the causes of those who have no voice.
Couldn't agree more.

I have to say I was a little worried about it at first, but apparently there is a pretty robust system in place that has been around for some years now and has been quite effective. This Time article actually made me change my mind about it: http://time.com/4116619/syrian-refugees-s<wbr />creening-process/. I don't blame people for being concerned, but I do blame people for ridiculous, disgusting rhetoric as we've been hearing from the usual dopes.
I couldn't agree more. Thank you for speaking so clearly about this most important issue of our day.
comments.subject: AGREED!

comments.article:
Although it's a typical thing from you, but i should state my gratitude.
Thank you,
Agree 100% George! Thank you for posting. Ignore the haters!
comments.subject: Well Said

comments.article:
I had no doubts about how big that heart was! It is buried deep in the pages of your books and here is extended out into our reality. Thank you for spreading the peace.

----Proud reader and fan.
comments.subject: Yes! Thank you!

comments.article: Sadly, I think most Americans would have warmly welcomed those people needing our help. And then politicians turned it into Us vs. Them vote-pandering.

Here in Canada, our new Prime Minister and his cabinet are fully committed to allowing 25,000 Syrian refugees into our country, and settlement plans are in motion now. It's a decision I whole-heartedly support.

Canada, like the USA, was built by the ideals illustrated by the New Colossus. It is a complicated issue, but no amount of political maneuvering will change the fact that these are human lives searching for shelter. And despite what some others think, human lives are more important than another notch on the federal budget books.

So again, well said.
comments.subject: Well said, George

comments.article:
I came here to say exactly that, though I will add something; looking at the numbers in the Toronto Star this morning, we could be welcoming 30000 refugees by years end thanks to the commitment of the premiers (Brad Wall excluded) to see Justin Trudeau's promise brought to life.

I personally look forward to welcoming are new brothers and sisters fleeing the horrors of their homeland.
comments.subject: Re: Well said, George
RE: Re: Well said, George

comments.article:
The right wingers are acting the same here in Europe too and they show how easy extremists and fascists on all sides play into each others hands.

The right dances perfectly to ISIS tune, who has declared that it is its set goal to sow discord between the muslim minorities living the west and the majority population. They want us to fear every single muslim, so that there is no save haven for the people who flee their horrors. And so that they can recrute the alienated teenagers.

I really hope that kindness, courage and basic human decency still win.

You do not see the world as black and white like many others.

It shows in your books and it shows in your personal opinions on matters like this.

Well said and I hope your message makes a difference to the many Syrian refugees that need it.
comments.subject: THIS is why I enjoy your writing!

comments.article: Unfortunately I can not agree with you, Mr Martin. Those "refugees" are not women with children.. Those are strong, young and mostly very aggressive MEN. Those men should fight for their country, not run away. Secondly, those "refugees" are not looking for safe place, they are looking for MONEY. They do not want to work, they want everything for free. I know the issue from experience - I live in Europe. I travelled Europe a lot... And this Europe is dying!! Please do not believe in propaganda - look for the facts, you can find them in the Internet. Listen to PEOPLE - not to government... Look what is going on on french/german/sweden streets! European people are afraid to live their houses because of aggressive muslims. Calais - a place in France is a place of war between french soldiers and syrian "refugees"... The european governments do not want to hear us - common people... The disaster is closer and closer... third world war is coming:( And no, its not fantasy...
comments.subject: You are wrong...

comments.upictitle: The Captain Of My Ship, The Master Of My Soul: Spider.
comments.article:
You realise the reason most of the refugees are men is because families in Syria decide it is too dangerous for women and children to make the trip, so what happens is the young men head out as refugees with the intent of finding jobs and money in Europe, to then pay for plane tickets and safer travel for the women and children?

That's why the majority are young men.

I'm a European person. I'm not afraid to live in my house because of aggressive Muslims.

comments.subject: Unemployment
RE: You are wrong...

comments.article:
George,

I broadly agree with your premise, and that refugees should be allowed into the United States and resettled peacefully. One of the things that I've wondered about though is the moral grandstanding aspect of the pro-let-'em-in side (my side). There's at least a feeling I get from reading opinions online of "Look at these rubes opposing the refugees. Their opinions are trash" instead of presenting an alternate narrative of: There IS heavy screening of refugees coming in (Medical, biometric, background investigation, etc) already.

Instead, my interpretation is that my/our side is too heavily invested in heavy moral grandstanding instead of presenting an alternative and more poignant narrative of what ACTUALLY happens when a Syrian attempts to enter the United States as a refugee. I wish that's what was focused on in arguments made on behalf of the refugees.

Anyways, lovely poem and agree with the sentiments. (Sorry for the rant)
comments.subject: Broadly in agreement

comments.article: Well said.
comments.subject: Re: Broadly in agreement

comments.article:
Hot topic! I do agree that we should accept refugees. The amount the US is planning on taking in is not that great as compared to the overall population of the US. While I have more right leaning tendencies about foreign policy, not helping out here is a bad move.

I do realize that there will be those that will be able to sneak in with the refugees and cause harm to US citizens. It only took 8 operatives and a handful providing support to cause that much death in Paris. That will be the price to pay for us to not entirely lose our soul as a generous and even handed people.
comments.subject: No good deed...

comments.article: Yes indeed. Let's weed out any wolves in sheep's clothing, and then let all the actual refugees on in!

Maybe in America this is normal because the US was build by immigrants , but not in Europe MR Martin. Here in Europe we have nothing to give , there is a lot of poverty , unemployement , crime , we can't welcome all the misery of the world , above all they don't have the same culture , the same tradition , the same religion , etc.

But i agree with you sir because you americans makes war at every damn places in this fucking world , just nearly 1 million death in Iraq . So take all the refugees you want , for your redemption .
